text: hi everyone
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time
for a review of the new floating points
and pharaoh sanders record
promises featuring the london symphony
orchestra
this is a collaboration between not one
not two but kind of three amazing names
in the world of music
one samuel t shepherd aka floating
points
a uk electronic music producer whose
short but eclectic discography is known
not just to cover idm and progressive
electronic music
but also classical and jazz as well two
saxophonist pharaoh sanders one of the
true living legends of
jazz has played with numerous greats
across his career
and is mostly known for his
contributions to spiritual jazz
so through some amazing alignment of the
stars these two have crossed over
and then decided a pivotal tool to help
their collaboration flourish
would be the london symphony orchestra
and of course
it's been released on the record label
that david byrne started in the late 80s
to
release brazilian and latin music that
he was obsessed with at the time as well
as his own solo stuff
and yes the label has dropped a ton of
great music in a variety of genres over
the years
i just thought this was something that
you should know so yes on promises what
we essentially have is a very unlikely
cross-section of figures
creating a meditative multi-movement new
jazz piece
with an orchestral twist and let me
specify that one more time we have one
piece on this record
going through multiple movements i point
that out because this piece moves
through what is essentially the same
cycle of cords for its 47-minute run
time but
breaks this progression up with
different instrumental palettes and
movements
over this theme so for one movement the
keys may be more prominent for another
the sax
for yet another the strings true to
sanders spiritual jazz roots
it's pretty entrancing in other words
it's a vibe
but it's also more than that often in my
reviews i will cite instances
on a song on a section of a song where
there's a lot of
movement a great progression but what
can also be great is when a piece of
music has
an alluring stillness to it a sense of
place artists who achieve this
tend to hang more in the ambient and
experimental realms but not always and
there are points where promises does
throw caution to the wind but for the
most part this is a
very stable composition whose magic is
displayed through these immensely
beautiful
instrumental shifts that i think will
woo nearly any music listener
there's also a cleanliness a clarity a
pristine
quality to the sound of this project
which i sort of expected given the
london symphony orchestra tie-in but it
doesn't take away from the heart and the
soul of the peace in my opinion
and for the most part complements the
more electronic aesthetics of the piece
too
the whole thing kicks off with this
beautiful first movement that
works in two parts essentially an
introduction to the foundational chords
of the piece
repeating them to the point where the
listener may
feel like they're being just brought
into
a lull a sense of serenity or
familiarity
and then pharaoh sanders begins running
through an expressive passionate sac
solo for the next five minutes i know
this is just the first step
of the record but between these glossy
keys and sanders course but
dynamic sax playing this is a sound i
just want to be lost in
even at this point there is a
weightlessness and a vastness
to promises that uh puts me in a state
of just
feeling like uh i'm spinning through a a
starry
open space i don't know what is up and
what is down the
introduction of strings and electronics
make the
next couple of shorter movements in this
piece melt into each other nicely
the core musical theme of the piece
remains strong and clear and constant
meanwhile shepard and sanders and the
orchestra are subtly diversifying the
instrumental palettes
movement four of the piece brings on
some oddly intimate humming and
vocalizations for a moment
it's uh interesting how this changes up
the vibe of everything so
instantaneously because
everything of it so far feels so
isolated but there's kind of like a
warmth
to that moment that just makes it feel
uh not so
um lonely the fiery sax playing that
comes later in
this particular movement is a lot darker
relies on deeper heavier tones
this smoothly transitions into movement
5 which gets a little chaotic
it's like everything we've been hearing
up until this point but the chaos of the
previous movement has brought
all of these elements up to a boiling
point there's more blending and bleeding
and volatility i feel like i'm listening
to
the musical equivalent to a chemical
reaction all of the elements here are
turning into a steamy soup of sound
on movement six much of the base
instrumentation flushes out to
really give a spotlight to the strings
there are some heavy
immense dense passages of music on this
one that i love
the bright orchestral arrangements
really do make for a climactic moment
movement 7 tones things down for some
spacey ambient electronics that
cycle into infinity then we get a
radical but simple change on the eighth
movement where
pretty much everything is replaced with
a very dirty organ
but the isolation of the organ in this
spot does allow
for creative musical embellishments on
the chords we've been hearing so far
in many ways the ninth and final
movement of the piece is
even more low-key you can tell shepard
and sanders are really trying to ease us
out of this experience the
orchestrations come back
it's very delicate it's quite cinematic
and in a nutshell that
is the piece that is promises and it's
quite lovely it's really one of the best
musical experiences i've had this year
there are some movements i think could
have used a bit more variation but
as is the mix the instrumentation here
is gorgeous is immaculate the whole
experience again
is truly meditative and entrancing and
creatively speaking this project is a
cool cross-section of jazz electronic
music and classical without any one of
those elements being to the detriment of
the other feeling a light to decent nine
on this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next
hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well
over here next to my head is another
video that you can check out hit that up
or the link to subscribe to the channel
anthony fantano music
forever
